questions.question: A 32 y/o pregnant woman presents for her routine antenatal check-up at 28 weeks gestation. She has a history of obesity but no previous history of diabetes. Her fasting plasma glucose level is 104 mg/dL, and her 2-hour plasma glucose level after a 75g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is 167 mg/dL. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate next step? levels.

options.A: Start lifestyle modifications and repeat OGTT at 32 weeks gestation.
options.B: Diagnose her with pre-existing diabetes and initiate insulin therapy.
options.C: Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose
options.D: Monitor her closely without intervention since her glucose levels are borderline.

questions.explanation: of blood glucose levels. Correct Answer: C) Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose levels. Explanation: According to WHO criteria, GDM is diagnosed if Diagnosis Gestational Diabetes Pre-existing Diabetes Timing During pregnancy Present before conception Criteria Fasting Plasma glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL ≥ 126 mg/dL (on two occasions) 1-hour plasma glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL ≥ 200 mg/dL (with hyperglycemic symptoms) 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL ≥ 200 mg/dL (during an OGTT in asymptomatic individuals) HbA1c ≥ 5.7-6.4% ≥ 6.5% Management Resolves after delivery. Requires intensive management before and during pregnancy. After experiencing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) during pregnancy, a mother may have an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes in later life. Lifestyle modifications are appropriate, but immediate diagnosis and management of GDM are necessary. Monitoring without intervention is inappropriate because the patient meets the criteria for GDM diagnosis and requires management to optimise maternal and fetal outcomes. Reference: William's Obstetrics Edition 26th Page 1069-1079

questions.question: A 28-year-old female, at 24 weeks of gestation, comes to the antenatal clinic for a regular checkup. Which of the following tests is most appropriate for diagnosing gestational diabetes mellitus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Oral glucose tolerance test Explanation: The most appropriate test for diagnosis of gestational diabetes is the oral glucose tolerance test. One-step approach recommended by WHO and IAD PSG (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Group): It is done in all pregnant females at 24-28 weeks. It is used both for screening and diagnostic purposes. The patient is advised to have an unrestricted diet for 72 hours, followed by overnight fasting, and then 75 gm of glucose is given. A total of 3 samples are taken: 1st sample: Fasting sample. 2nd sample: After 1 hour of 75 gm of glucose. 3rd sample: After 2 hours of 75 gm of glucose. Interpretation: If any 1 value is abnormal, the patient is considered as having gestational diabetes. mg/dL mmol/litre Fasting ≤ 92 5.1 1 hour ≤ 180 10.1 2 hours ≤ 153 8.5 The two-step approach advocated by ACOG is not recommended due to its two-step process: Oral glucose challenge test: Performed by giving 50 gm of glucose irrespective of previous meals and no fasting required. Glucose tolerance test: Confirmatory test is done using 100 gm of glucose after overnight fasting of 8 hours. Fasting plasma glucose (FPG) (Option A) measures blood glucose after an overnight fast; useful for screening for diabetes but not sufficient alone to diagnose GDM. A random plasma glucose test (Option C) measures blood glucose at any time of the day; it is not specific enough to diagnose GDM, as glucose levels can vary widely. HbA1c (glycated haemoglobin) (Option D) reflects average blood glucose over the past 2-3 months; useful for diagnosing pre-existing diabetes but not typically used for GDM diagnosis. Reference: 1. William's Obstetrics Edition 26th Page 1079 2. International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups Recommendations on the Diagnosis and Classification of Hyperglycemia in Pregnancy - PMC

questions.question: A 32 y/o pregnant woman presents for her routine prenatal visit at 32 weeks gestation. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, well-controlled with metformin. Despite following the dietary recommendations, she reports occasional difficulty managing her blood glucose levels. Which complication is most likely associated with her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Macrosomia Explanation: Macrosomia, defined as fetal weight above the 90th percentile for gestational age, is highly associated with diabetes in pregnancy, particularly when maternal blood glucose levels are not well controlled. Fetal macrosomia with birth weight >4 kg (>90th percentile) probably results from: Maternal hyperglycemia → hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the fetal islets of Langerhans → increased secretion of fetal insulin → stimulates carbohydrate utilisation and accumulation of fat. Insulin-like growth factors (IGF-I and II) are also involved in fetal growth and adiposity. Elevating maternal free fatty acid (FFA) in diabetes leads to increased transfer to the fetus → acceleration of triglyceride synthesis → adiposity. With good diabetic control, the incidence of macrosomia is markedly reduced. This condition increases the risk of complications during delivery, such as Shoulder dystocia (Fetal cause). Cesarean delivery (Maternal cause) Indication: Weight >4.5kg. Complications of gestational diabetes mellitus: Maternal Fetal Preterm labour. Urinary tract infections and vulvovaginitis. Increased incidence of preeclampsia. Polyhydramnios. Maternal distress. Puerperal sepsis. Lactation failure PPH (post-partum hemorrhage) Fetal hyperglycemia. Macrosomia. Polycythemia Hyperglycemia Delayed lung maturity NEC (necrotising enterocolitis) Hyperbilirubinemia Hypocalcemia Hypomagnesimia Overt Diabetes can lead to complications like IUD, IUGR, pre-eclampsia and ketoacidosis. Oligohydramnios (Option A) or reduced amniotic fluid volume, can occur in pregnancies complicated by diabetes if there is vasculopathy. Still, it is not the most likely maternal problem associated with a fetus that is significantly larger than average (macrosomia). Fetal growth restriction (Option B) can occur in pregnancies complicated by diabetes if there is vasculopathy. However, it is not the most likely maternal problem associated with a fetus with macrosomia (GDM). Placental abruption (Option D) is a serious complication where the placenta separates from the uterine wall prematurely. While it can occur in pregnancies complicated by diabetes due to vascular changes, it is less commonly associated with macrosomia. Reference: William's Obstetrics Edition 26th Page 1081 , 1082

questions.question: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with known case of overt diabetes mellitus in her second trimester complains of persistent nausea and vomiting. She has poor glycemic control and these symptoms have worsened over the past few weeks. What pre-existing diabetic complication is most likely contributing to her current symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Diabetic Neuropathy Explanation: Diabetic neuropathy during pregnancy can manifest as diabetic gastropathy. It involves damage to the nerves that control the stomach muscles, leading to delayed gastric emptying. The patient experiences persistent nausea and vomiting. It is treated with metoclopramide and domperidone. Diabetic Retinopathy (Option A) is characterised by neovascularisation, microaneurysms and blot haemorrhages, it can lead to vision loss. Diabetic Ketoacidosis (Option B) is caused by reduced insulin, beta mimetic administration for tocolysis, and steroids for lung maturity. It presents with symptoms like excessive thirst, frequent urination, abdominal pain, and rapid breathing. Diabetic Nephropathy (Option C) is detected when microalbuminuria is 30 to 300 mg/24 hr. Associated with pre-eclampsia, preterm labour, and fetal growth restriction.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman with gestational diabetes(GDM) delivers a 5.1 kg baby boy at 39 weeks of gestation. The baby appears jittery and lethargic a few hours after birth. Which of the following neonatal complications is the most likely cause of the infant's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hypoglycemia. Explanation: The case of a mother with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and a 5.1 kg baby highlights macrosomia caused by GDM. Infants born to mothers with GDM are exposed to elevated maternal glucose levels in the womb, which triggers fetal hyperinsulinemia. Reference: William's Obstetrics Edition 26th Page 1082

questions.question: A 35 y/o with pre-existing diabetes presents to the labour ward at 38 weeks of gestation in labour. She has a history of poor glycemic control throughout her pregnancy. The baby presents with features of heart failure at 8 weeks of life. On examination, the baby is found to have pan systolic murmur. What is the most common anomaly seen in babies born to mothers with pre-existing diabetes?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ventricular septal defect Explanation: Ventricular septal defect is the most common anomaly in infants of diabetic mothers. It is an abnormal opening in the septum between the heart's ventricles, allowing blood to pass from the left to the right side of the heart. The other anomaly that has a direct correlation with babies of mothers with pre-existing diabetes is caudal regression syndrome. regression syndrome" data-author="Donaire AeS. SethuramE. KitsosP. AnkolaR. Benamanahali" data-hash="369" data-license="NA" d ata-source="https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Congenital-Bilateral-Knee-Hyperextension-in-a-Ae-Sethura m/e71ecd38eb353273e11be1396a2da6b059a2903e/figure/1" data-tags="December2024" height="387" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/hLtFPQEmk8WFqd1VJ4nw1734670335.jpg" width="500" /> https://www.indianpediatrics.net/jan2001/jan-98.htm Major birth defects in infants of diabetic mothers: CNS & skeletal CVS Renal Gastrointestinal Others Neural tube defects VSD, ASD Renal agenesis Duodenal atresia Single umbilical artery Anencephaly Coarctation of aorta Hydronephrosis Anorectal atresia Microcephaly Transposition of great vessels Doube ureter Omphalocele Caudal regression syndrome Situs inversus Polycystic kidneys Tracheo- esophageal atresia Sacral agenesis Tetralogy of Fallot Transposition of the great arteries (Option A) has a direct correlation with babies of mothers with pre-existing diabetes and is the most specific cardiac anomaly associated, but is uncommon. Atrial septal defect (ASD) (Option C) : There is an abnormal opening in the septum between the heart's upper chambers (atria). While it can occur in infants of diabetic mothers, it does not have a direct correlation.. Coarctation of the aorta (Option D) is a narrowing of the aorta, the main artery that carries blood from the heart to the body. It can occur in babies of diabetic mothers,it does not have a direct correlation. Reference: William's Obstetrics Edition 26th Page 1071-1073

questions.question: A 30 y/o female came at 28 wks gestation with 75 gm OGTT report showing 2 hr postprandial (PP) blood glucose value of 170 mg/dl. She was started on dietary modification and exercise. She came for follow up after 2 wks, her FBS is 120 mg/dl & 2hr postprandial is 160 mg/dl.. What is the best treatment for her now?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Insulin Explanation: Insulin is DOC in Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). 75gm 2 hr PP values > 140 suggest GDM, which is uncontrollable on a diet in the given scenario. Insulin dose: 75gm 2hr PP value (mg/dl) Insulin dose Time of day 120-160 4 units 30 min before breakfast 160-200 6 units 30 min before breakfast >200 8 units 30 min before breakfast FBS >95 Add 2 units Before dinner Continue dietary modification and exercise (Option A) is wrong because once dietary modification and exercise are started, the goals to be attained after 2 weeks are: FBS: 70-95 mg/dL. 1 hour post prandial: <140 mg/dL. 2 hour post prandial: <120 mg/dL. HbA1C: <6%. This goal is not attained in the given scenario. So, insulin needs to be started. Glibenclamide and Metformin (Option C&D) are the only oral hypoglycemic agents that can be given in gestational diabetes. They do not cause any teratogenic effect. But first line DOC in GDM is insulin. Other oral hypoglycemic drugs are C/I in GDM. Reference: William's obstetrics edition 26th, pg 1082

questions.question: A 34 y/o G2P1 woman comes at 39 wks gestation and her blood sugar levels are well controlled on insulin. Induction of labor is planned for her. Which of the following is wrong statement regarding her management?

options.B: If sugar levels <70 mg/dl give 5%dextrose at 100-150 ml/hr
options.C: If sugar levels >100 mg/dl give insulin at 1 - 1.25 units/hr
options.D: Give morning dose of insulin on day of induction

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Give morning dose of insulin on day of induction Explanation: Morning dose of insulin is omitted on the day of induction. Important points to remember on management of GDM mother during induction of labor: Evening dose of insulin before the day of induction is administered. The morning dose of insulin is omitted on the day of induction. Start normal saline (NS) at 100 - 125 ml/hr (option A). If blood sugar levels <70 mg/dl give 5%dextrose at 100-150 ml/hr (option B). If blood sugar levels >100 mg/dl give insulin at 1 - 1.25 units/hr (option C). Ideally blood sugar levels maintained between 70-100 mg/dl. Hourly monitoring of blood glucose is done. Reference: William's obstetrics edition 26th, 1078

questions.question: A 37 y/o primigravida with type II DM on insulin is seen in antenatal OPD. Which of the following is not routinely checked on her further visits to diagnose complications of diabetes in her?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : D) Amniotic fluid index (AFI) for oligohydramnios Explanation: Fetal Doppler is not routinely done in diabetic pregnancies, it is done if the pregnancy is complicated with fetal growth restriction. However fetal growth scans are recommended. Fundus examination (Option A) is done to check for diabetic retinopathy. It will have proliferative retinopathy with neovascularisation and microaneurysms. Fetal Echo (Option B) is recommended between 22 - 24 weeks to detect fetal CVS anomalies with pregestational diabetes, especially if uncontrolled . A 24-hour urinary protein test (Option C) is done to diagnose diabetic nephropathy. In diabetic nephropathy, creatinine clearance is reduced, or there is persistent proteinuria ( ≥ 300 mg/24 hours) during the first 20 weeks of gestation. Reference: William's Obstetrics edition 26th, pg 1074

questions.question: A G2P1 is diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), her blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin. What is the appropriate gestational age at which her delivery is recommended?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 39 wks Explanation: A GDM female well controlled on insulin/drugs is delivered at 39 weeks to 39 weeks + 6 days according to ACOG guidelines. ACOG guidelines: Case Time of delivery Well-controlled on diet 39 weeks to 40 weeks + 6 days Well-controlled on insulin/drugs 39 weeks to 39 weeks + 6 days Poorly controlled: Individualise Delivery between 37 weeks & 38 weeks + 6 days may be justified. Delivery between 34 weeks & 36 weeks + 6 days reserved for: Failure of in-hospital glycemic control. Abnormal fetal testing. Reference: Updated ACOG Guidance on Gestational Diabetes - The ObG Project
